text: Hello everyone! This is Alex, and you're tuning in to the TG-DCA update, broadcasting live at 8:33 PM UTC on October 5th, 2024. I'm thrilled to bring you the latest in crypto news along with our panel of experts. Let's dive right in!

Thanks, Alex. So, our next story is about a meme coin trader who missed out on a whopping $25 million payout after selling their HIPPO tokens too early on the Sui Network. Just goes to show how unpredictable the crypto world can be, doesn't it?

Absolutely, Beth. It's a wild ride indeed. This trader sold a staggering 1.8 billion HIPPO for about $11,000, only to watch the value skyrocket shortly after. If they'd held on just a bit longer, they could have made a fortune. The Sui Network's impressive transaction speeds and the rapid rise of HIPPO have turned quite a few heads.

Interesting, Charlie. But let's also consider the liquidity issues. A single wallet controls 76% of the total HIPPO supply. This could potentially lead to price manipulation and a rapid decline in value if that holder decides to sell. It's a great reminder of the risks involved in trading these volatile assets.

That's a valid point, Dana. It's always a gamble. Do you cash out early and secure profits, or hold on for potential massive gains? And with these liquidity issues, it will be interesting to see how HIPPO's future unfolds.

Shifting gears a bit, let's talk about our next story. Pickspot has chosen peaq as its Layer 1 solution to tackle the last-mile delivery challenge in Africa. A fascinating example of how blockchain can be applied to solve real-world problems.

Indeed, Dana. Peaq and Pickspot are teaming up to provide an innovative solution to a pressing problem. By using peaq's layer-1 blockchain as the backbone of Pickspot's logistics solutions, they're aiming to optimize Africa's last-mile delivery process. It's a timely move, considering the growth of Africa's eCommerce sector.

I'm particularly intrigued by Pickspot's approach. They're using community-owned smart parcel lockers that operate as NFTs. Local residents can send and receive parcels while earning crypto rewards. It's a smart way to support informal trade networks, which are quite prevalent in Africa.

And let's not forget to mention the importance of community involvement in all of this. Both the CEO of Pickspot and the co-founder of peaq emphasized this. The integration of blockchain technology can certainly help drive economic growth in such regions.
True, Charlie. It's a compelling case study in how blockchain can be leveraged to solve real-world problems, especially in emerging markets. And it's certainly a topic worth exploring further.
